Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. Accurately documenting the impacts human activities have on natural populations is a pressing goal in biology. However, in many cases we are limited to studies of present-day populations that exist well after human transformation of the landscape. This presents a major challenge for understanding how different human activities impact populations. Museum collections house long term series of specimens that often span historical, human-induced changes. Recent DNA sequencing advances enable access to genomic data from these specimens, providing an invaluable resource for directly connecting population responses to specific human activities. This project leverages a large series of historic specimens for tidal marsh Savannah Sparrows collected along the California coast over the last 130 years. The fellow will collect morphological and genomic data from these specimens to characterize population responses to salt pond development and urbanization in the San Francisco Bay area.

The fellow will develop a sequence capture array to generate genomic material from Savannah Sparrow specimens collected from multiple localities along the California coast and six time points between the 1880s and the present. Morphological data will also be collected from these specimens. These data will be connected with spatial and temporal data on climate and landscape transformation to understand (1) temporal variation in allele frequencies at loci locally adapted to salinity and temperature variation; (2) the impact of tidal marsh habitat loss to changing patterns of population size and gene flow among tidal marsh populations; and (3) the link between changing demography and selective pressures with divergence in adaptive phenotypic traits. The fellow will receive training in extracting and processing degraded DNA from museum specimens, designing sequence capture arrays, and using the bioinformatic pipelines required to process and analyze this data. Data will be linked to specimens in the museum database Arctos, which will then be used to design undergraduate educational modules that highlight the power of museum resources for biological inference. Undergraduate students at UC Berkeley will be recruited to work on this project. Finally, throughout the San Francisco Bay area there is enormous effort currently underway to restore tidal wetlands. The results from this work will inform management strategies about how much habitat is needed to maintain population sizes and population connectivity at historic levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accurately documenting the impacts human activities have on natural populations is a pressing goal in biology. However, in many cases we are limited to studies of present-day populations that exist well after human transformation of the landscape. This presents a major challenge for understanding how different human activities impact populations. Museum collections house long term series of specimens that often span historical, human-induced changes. Recent sequencing advances enable access to genomic data from these specimens, providing an invaluable resource for directly connecting population responses to specific human activities. This project took advantage of dense temporal and spatial sampling of Savannah Sparrows (Passerculus sandwichensis) that were collected from along the California coast over the last 130 years. This sampling includes time-series of specimens that span extensive development of critical coastal habitat for this species and provided a unique opportunity to leverage biological collections to understand population responses to anthropogenic change. The funded project integrated morphological, genomic, climate, and other landscape data to understand: (1) temporal variation in allele frequencies at loci locally adapted to salinity and temperature variation; (2) the impact of tidal marsh habitat loss to changing patterns of population size and gene flow among tidal marsh populations; and (3) the link between changing demography and selective pressures with divergence in adaptive phenotypic traits.

 

Morphological characters were measured from over 1000 specimens sampled between 1862 and 2017 from throughout California. Analysis of this dataset found that bill size increased the most in coastal habitats that have experienced the greatest increase in temperature and decrease in humidity over time. In addition to being critical for foraging ecology, bills can provide important thermoregulatory benefits to birds by allowing them to shed excess body heat from across the bill surface. Importantly, in hotter and drier climates using bills to keep cool can help save water by relying less on water evaporation to stay cool. Based on the relationship between bill size and amounts of daily water loss, it was estimated that observed increases in bill size in some populations could contribute to significant water savings. A potentially important adaptation for coping with hotter and drier conditions. 

 

To understand patterns of genomic change in tidal marsh Savannah Sparrows in response to human activities, The project took advantage of a genome sequencing approach known as exome capture. This approach targets the regions of the genome that encode different proteins. This approach is particularly suitable for sequencing the degraded and fragmented DNA of historic specimens. A custom array targeting the coding regions of nearly 14,000 genes was developed. This capture array was used to generate genomic sequence data from 183 Savannah Sparrows sampled over the past 130 years in California. Analysis of this genomic dataset from historical and modern Savannah Sparrows shows evidence for shifting patterns of gene flow among populations over time. Second, decreases in genetic diversity were found over the last 100+ years, especially in more vulnerable populations, such as the California state endangered subspecies: Belding?s Savannah Sparrow. Finally, analyses found evidence for selection acting on genes associated with osmoregulatory functions that could potentially be evolving in response to increasing temperatures and/or salinities over time. Change in these environmental parameters might be exacerbating the challenges of maintaining salt and water balance in a high salinity environment for these sparrows. 

 

            The results of this research have been disseminated widely, including: several presentations at the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, presentations at three scientific meetings, and one peer-reviewed manuscript in press in an open access journal. Through the course of the funded project, PI Benham received extensive training in sequencing, bioinformatics, and other analytical techniques. PI Benham also mentored several undergraduate and graduate students in data collection, bioinformatics, and morphological analyses. Finally, the results from this work should be informative for management strategies about how much habitat is needed to maintain population sizes and population connectivity at historic levels.
